questions.text: Pencil is fine for written answers if your writing is neat.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned for marking. Pencil often appears too faint to read. Use pen for all written responses.
questions.studyTip: Pen for answers. Pencil only for graphs and diagrams.

questions.text: Assessors mark scanned images, so ink pen is essential for clear responses.
questions.explanation: Your paper is scanned, not marked directly. Ink shows up clearly; pencil can be unreadable or faded.
questions.studyTip: Dark blue or black ink scans best.

questions.text: If your handwriting is messy, assessors will figure out what you meant.
questions.explanation: Assessors can only mark what they can read. Unclear digits like 4 vs 9 or 1 vs 7 may be marked wrong.
questions.studyTip: Write digits clearly. A misread 4 or 9 costs marks.

questions.text: You should take care to form digits clearly, especially 4 and 9, which can look similar.
questions.explanation: Assessors often see ambiguous digits. Make 4, 9, 1, and 7 clearly distinguishable.
questions.studyTip: Cross your 7s and close your 4s properly.

questions.text: For multi-mark questions, the correct final answer is enough to get full marks.
questions.explanation: Working is mandatory for questions worth more than 1 mark. Without it, you can't earn partial credit if your answer is wrong.
questions.studyTip: No working = no marks, even if the answer is right.

questions.text: Showing your working allows you to earn partial marks even if your final answer is incorrect.
questions.explanation: Each correct step shows understanding. Partial marks come from correct method even if you make an arithmetic slip.
questions.studyTip: Write the formula, show substitution, then give the answer.

questions.text: Reading time is just for reading questions once through quickly.
questions.explanation: Use reading time strategically: identify key information, note 'show that' questions, and plan your approach.
questions.studyTip: Spot the tricky questions in reading time. Plan before you write.

questions.text: During reading time, you should identify questions that require 'show that' or use earlier answers.
questions.explanation: These questions need careful planning. Spotting them early helps you approach them systematically.
questions.studyTip: Mark questions that build on earlier parts—get those right first.

questions.text: Once you've answered a question, move on immediately to save time.
questions.explanation: Re-reading helps you check you've answered all parts and in the required format. Many marks are lost to incomplete answers.
questions.studyTip: Quick re-read catches missing parts and format errors.

questions.text: After answering, you should re-read the question to ensure you've addressed all parts.
questions.explanation: Questions often have multiple parts. Re-reading ensures you haven't missed anything.
questions.studyTip: Count the parts. Answer them all.

questions.text: If your calculation gives an answer, it must be correct regardless of whether it makes sense.
questions.explanation: Always sense-check. If a biscuit weighs several kilograms or a percentage is over 100%, something is wrong.
questions.studyTip: Does your answer make real-world sense? If not, check again.

questions.text: You should check that your calculated values are realistic within the context of the question.
questions.explanation: A single item costing $50,000 or a person being 15 metres tall signals an error. Context matters.
questions.studyTip: Pause and ask: is this answer reasonable?

questions.text: If the question asks for a percentage, writing just the number without % is fine.
questions.explanation: If a percentage is required, include the % symbol. '25' is not the same as '25%' in an answer.
questions.studyTip: Question asks for percentage? Write the % symbol.

questions.text: When a question specifies a format (percentage, decimal, fraction), you must use that format.
questions.explanation: Marks are often tied to the correct format. Give exactly what's asked for.
questions.studyTip: Match the format: %, decimal, or fraction as required.

questions.text: Writing $77.55 as 77.55$ is acceptable since the meaning is clear.
questions.explanation: The $ symbol must come before the number: $77.55, not 77.55$. Incorrect notation loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Dollar sign goes first: $77.55

questions.text: Money amounts must have the $ symbol at the start and cents written to two decimal places.
questions.explanation: $5.00 not $5. $12.50 not $12.5. The $ goes before the number, always.
questions.studyTip: $XX.XX format—symbol first, two decimal places.

concepts.title: Round only at the final step

questions.text: Rounding numbers at each step of a calculation keeps things simple and tidy.
questions.explanation: Rounding at intermediate steps causes accumulated error. Your final answer will be wrong.
questions.studyTip: Keep all decimals until the very last step.

questions.text: Rounding should only occur at the final step to avoid accumulated error.
questions.explanation: Small rounding errors multiply through calculations. Wait until the end to round.
questions.studyTip: Carry full accuracy through. Round only the final answer.

questions.text: Rounding to 2 decimal places and rounding to 2 significant figures always give the same result.
questions.explanation: They're different. 0.00456 to 2 d.p. is 0.00, but to 2 s.f. is 0.0046. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: Decimal places count from the point. Sig figs count from the first non-zero.

questions.text: You must understand the difference between rounding to decimal places and significant figures.
questions.explanation: Questions specify which one. Using the wrong method loses marks even if your calculation is correct.
questions.studyTip: Read carefully: d.p. or s.f.? They give different answers.

questions.text: Writing $52 × $1833.30 = $95,331.60 − $2000 = $93,331.60 is correct mathematical notation.
questions.explanation: This 'chain' of equals signs is mathematically incorrect. $52 × $1833.30 does not equal $95,331.60 − $2000.
questions.studyTip: Each line should be a separate, correct statement.

questions.text: Calculations should be separated into distinct steps, not chained with multiple equals signs.
questions.studyTip: One equals sign per line. Keep statements mathematically true.

questions.text: If no rounding instruction is given, you can round to whatever seems sensible.
questions.explanation: No instruction means give an exact answer. '11.42' is required, not '11.4' or '11'.
questions.studyTip: No rounding instruction = exact answer required.

questions.text: When no rounding instruction is given, you should provide an exact value.
questions.explanation: The exam instructions state this clearly. Don't round unless specifically told to.
questions.studyTip: Check: does it say 'correct to...'? If not, give the exact answer.

questions.text: To find a percentage, divide and your answer is the percentage.
questions.explanation: Dividing gives a decimal. Multiply by 100 to convert to a percentage. 0.25 × 100 = 25%.
questions.studyTip: Decimal × 100 = percentage.

questions.text: Converting a decimal to a percentage requires multiplying by 100.
questions.explanation: 0.375 = 37.5%. Many students forget this final step and lose marks.

questions.text: Percentage difference is just the difference between two numbers.
questions.explanation: Percentage difference = (difference ÷ original) × 100. You must identify the correct denominator.
questions.studyTip: Use the formula: (new − old) ÷ old × 100%

questions.text: Calculating percentage difference requires dividing by the original value, not the new value.
questions.explanation: The formula is on your formula sheet. The denominator is the original (starting) value.
questions.studyTip: Percentage change: divide by what you started with.

questions.text: A ratio like 250:500 is fine as a final answer.
questions.explanation: Ratios should be simplified to lowest terms. 250:500 = 1:2.
questions.studyTip: Simplify ratios like you simplify fractions.

questions.text: Ratios should be expressed in their simplest form.
questions.explanation: Find the highest common factor and divide both parts. 250:500 becomes 1:2.
questions.studyTip: Divide both sides by the HCF to simplify.

questions.text: When calculating with measurements, the units will sort themselves out.
questions.explanation: You must ensure units are consistent before calculating. Can't add metres to centimetres directly.
questions.studyTip: Convert to the same unit before you calculate.

questions.text: Before calculating, you should ensure all measurements use the same units.
questions.explanation: Convert first, then calculate. Mixing units causes errors that are hard to spot.
questions.studyTip: Same units = safe calculation.

questions.text: A quick glance at a graph is enough to answer questions about it.
questions.explanation: Graphs contain precise information. Read scales, check units, and identify exact values carefully.
questions.studyTip: Check the axis labels and scale before reading values.

questions.text: When answering questions involving graphs, you should carefully identify important information from the graph.
questions.explanation: Use reading time to examine graphs. Note scales, units, and key features.
questions.studyTip: Axes, scale, units, title—check them all.

questions.text: Stating a single statistic from a graph is enough to describe a comparison.
questions.explanation: Comparisons require reference to both things being compared. '50% were concerned' isn't a comparison—you need to compare groups.
questions.studyTip: Compare means: 'A is more than B' or 'X compared to Y'.

questions.text: When comparing data, you must reference both elements being compared, not just state single values.
questions.explanation: 'Group A had 64% compared to Group B's 50%' is a comparison. Just stating one number isn't.
questions.studyTip: Use comparison words: more than, less than, compared to.

questions.text: The median is always the number in the middle of the data as it's written.
questions.explanation: Data must be ordered first. Then find the middle value, or average of two middle values if there's an even count.
questions.studyTip: Order the data first, then find the middle.

questions.text: For an even number of values, the median is the average of the two middle values.
questions.explanation: 27 values: median is the 14th. 10 values: median is average of 5th and 6th.
questions.studyTip: Even count? Average the two middle values.

questions.text: The mean and median are the same thing, just different names.
questions.explanation: Mean is the average (sum ÷ count). Median is the middle value. They're different calculations.
questions.studyTip: Mean = average. Median = middle. Know the difference.

questions.text: You must distinguish between mean (average) and median (middle value) as they give different results.
questions.explanation: Many students calculate the mean when asked for median, or vice versa. Read carefully.
questions.studyTip: Check what's asked: mean or median?

questions.text: When asked about 'the intercept', you should discuss both x and y intercepts.
questions.explanation: In Foundation Maths, 'the intercept' means the y-intercept (vertical axis). Don't discuss the x-intercept unless asked.
questions.studyTip: 'The intercept' = y-intercept. Don't overthink it.

questions.text: When asked to interpret the intercept, focus on the y-intercept and its meaning in context.
questions.explanation: The y-intercept shows the value when x = 0. Interpret what this means in the real-world context.
questions.studyTip: What does the starting value (when x = 0) represent?

questions.text: All data that uses words instead of numbers is categorical.
questions.explanation: Categorical variables are categories or groups: payment type, colour preference, education level.
questions.studyTip: Categories = categorical. Measurements = numerical.

questions.text: If data can be any number in a range, it must be discrete numerical data.
questions.explanation: Continuous data can take any value in a range (height, weight, time). Discrete data is countable (number of children).
questions.studyTip: Can you have 2.5 children? No = discrete. Can you be 165.3 cm? Yes = continuous.

questions.text: To remove GST from a price, subtract 10%.
questions.explanation: Wrong method. To find the pre-GST price, divide by 1.1, not subtract 10%. $44 ÷ 1.1 = $40, not $44 − $4.40 = $39.60.
questions.studyTip: Remove GST: divide by 1.1. Add GST: multiply by 1.1.

questions.text: To find the GST-inclusive price from a GST-exclusive price, multiply by 1.1.
questions.explanation: GST is 10%. $40 × 1.1 = $44 including GST. This adds 10% correctly.
questions.studyTip: Price without GST × 1.1 = price with GST.

questions.text: Simple interest adds interest to the principal each period, so subsequent interest is calculated on a larger amount.
questions.explanation: That's compound interest. Simple interest is calculated only on the original principal each time.
questions.studyTip: Simple interest = same amount each period. Compound = grows each period.

questions.text: Simple interest is calculated using I = PRT, where interest is based only on the original principal.
questions.explanation: Simple interest doesn't compound. $1000 at 5% for 3 years = $1000 × 0.05 × 3 = $150 interest total.
questions.studyTip: I = PRT. Principal stays the same throughout.

questions.text: With a reducing balance loan, the interest amount stays the same each period.
questions.explanation: Interest is calculated on the remaining balance. As you pay off principal, the balance decreases, so interest decreases too.
questions.studyTip: Reducing balance = interest gets smaller over time.

questions.text: On a reducing balance loan, interest decreases over time because it's calculated on the remaining balance.
questions.explanation: Each payment reduces the principal. Lower principal means lower interest next time.
questions.studyTip: Balance goes down → interest goes down.

questions.text: Superannuation is money taken out of your pay as tax.
questions.explanation: Superannuation is retirement savings, contributed by your employer on top of your wages. It's different from tax.
questions.studyTip: Super = retirement savings, not tax.

questions.text: Superannuation is money contributed by employers toward an employee's retirement savings.
questions.explanation: It's a percentage of your salary paid into a super fund. You can also make voluntary contributions.
questions.studyTip: Super is for your retirement—separate from your salary.

questions.text: Gross pay is the amount you actually receive in your bank account.
questions.explanation: Gross pay is before deductions. Net pay (take-home pay) is what you actually receive after tax and other deductions.
questions.studyTip: Gross = before deductions. Net = what you actually get.

questions.text: Net pay is calculated by subtracting tax and other deductions from gross pay.
questions.explanation: Gross − tax − other deductions = net (take-home) pay.
questions.studyTip: Net = Gross minus all the deductions.

questions.text: Area and perimeter use the same formula for rectangles.
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2(l + w), adding the sides. Area = l × w, multiplying length by width. Different formulas, different units.
questions.studyTip: Perimeter = add sides (units). Area = multiply (square units).

questions.text: Area is measured in square units (m², cm²) while perimeter is measured in linear units (m, cm).
questions.explanation: Area covers a surface (square units). Perimeter is a distance around (linear units).
questions.studyTip: Area = m². Perimeter = m. Check your units.

questions.text: To convert a fraction to a decimal, multiply the numerator by the denominator.
questions.explanation: Divide the numerator by the denominator. ¾ = 3 ÷ 4 = 0.75.
questions.studyTip: Fraction to decimal: top ÷ bottom.

questions.text: Converting a fraction to a decimal requires dividing the numerator by the denominator.
questions.explanation: ⅜ = 3 ÷ 8 = 0.375. The fraction bar means divide.
questions.studyTip: Numerator ÷ denominator = decimal.

questions.text: 0.5% expressed as a decimal is 0.5.
To convert a percentage to a decimal, divide by 100.
questions.explanation: 37.5% ÷ 100 = 0.375. Move the decimal point two places left.
questions.studyTip: % to decimal: divide by 100 (or move decimal 2 left).

concepts.title: Percentage is not just a number

questions.text: If you calculate 0.25 and the question asks for a percentage, writing 0.25 is correct.
questions.explanation: 0.25 is a decimal, not a percentage. You need to write 25%. Many students forget to convert.
questions.studyTip: Percentage question? Answer must have % or say 'percent'.

questions.text: A decimal like 0.25 must be multiplied by 100 and expressed as 25% when a percentage is required.
questions.explanation: Percentage means 'per hundred'. 0.25 = 25 per hundred = 25%.
questions.studyTip: Decimal × 100 = percentage. Don't forget the conversion.

questions.text: A difference of $6 between two prices is automatically a 6% change.
questions.explanation: Percentage change depends on the original value. $6 from $100 is 6%, but $6 from $50 is 12%.
questions.studyTip: Same difference, different percentages. Always calculate properly.

questions.text: Percentage change must be calculated relative to the original value, not assumed from the difference.
questions.explanation: Use (change ÷ original) × 100. The raw difference tells you nothing about the percentage.
questions.studyTip: Percentage change formula is on your sheet. Use it.

questions.text: If you earn above a tax bracket threshold, you pay that rate on all your income.
questions.explanation: Tax brackets apply only to income within each bracket. You don't pay the top rate on everything.
questions.studyTip: Tax is calculated in layers, not all at one rate.

questions.text: Tax is calculated progressively, with different rates applying to different portions of income.
questions.explanation: Income up to $18,200 might be tax-free, the next portion at 19%, and so on. Each bracket has its own rate.
questions.studyTip: Work through each bracket separately, then add up the tax.

questions.text: A quarter circle has the same area formula as a full circle.
questions.explanation: A quarter circle is ¼ of the full circle area. Multiply πr² by ¼, not by 1.
questions.studyTip: Quarter = ÷4. Half = ÷2. Full = ×1.

questions.text: When calculating areas of partial circles, you must multiply the full circle area by the appropriate fraction.
questions.explanation: Quarter circle = πr² × ¼. Semicircle = πr² × ½. Match the fraction to the portion.
questions.studyTip: What fraction of a circle? Apply that fraction to πr².

questions.text: A 10% increase followed by a 10% decrease returns you to the original value.
questions.explanation: $100 + 10% = $110. $110 − 10% = $99. You end up lower than you started.
questions.studyTip: Percentages don't cancel out. The base changes.

questions.text: Successive percentage changes must be calculated step by step, not simply added or subtracted.
questions.explanation: Each percentage is calculated on the new amount, not the original. Work through each step.
questions.studyTip: Calculate each change on the result of the previous one.

questions.text: If interest gets smaller on a reducing balance loan, the interest rate is decreasing.
questions.explanation: The rate stays the same. The interest amount decreases because it's applied to a smaller balance.
questions.studyTip: Rate stays constant. Amount changes with the balance.

questions.text: On a reducing balance loan, the interest rate stays constant while the interest amount decreases.
questions.explanation: Rate (e.g., 5% p.a.) is fixed. Amount = rate × balance. Smaller balance means smaller amount.
questions.studyTip: Same rate, shrinking balance, shrinking interest.

questions.text: When calculating interest on a purchase, use the full purchase price as the principal.
questions.explanation: If a deposit was paid, subtract it first. Interest is calculated on the amount borrowed, not the full price.
questions.studyTip: Principal = full price − deposit. Then calculate interest.

questions.text: When a deposit has been paid, interest should be calculated on the remaining balance only.
questions.explanation: Deposit reduces what you owe. Interest applies only to the balance you're actually borrowing.
questions.studyTip: Paid a deposit? Take it off before calculating interest.

questions.text: To find the value needed to achieve a target mean, subtract the current mean from the target mean.
questions.explanation: You need to work with totals. New total = target mean × new count. Required value = new total − current total.
questions.studyTip: Work with totals: target mean × count = required total.

questions.text: To find a required value for a target mean, calculate using totals rather than just the means.
questions.explanation: If 10 items average $100, total = $1000. For 11 items to average $120, need $1320 total. 11th item = $320.
questions.studyTip: Total = mean × count. Use this relationship.

questions.text: For 'show that' questions, if you get the given answer, you've done enough.
questions.explanation: 'Show that' requires every step to be visible. Assumed calculations and jumps in logic lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Show that = show ALL the working to get there.

questions.text: 'Show that' questions require you to display all working steps, not just arrive at the answer.
questions.explanation: The process matters as much as the result. Write each calculation clearly and logically.
questions.studyTip: Every step visible. No shortcuts in 'show that' questions.

questions.text: One long equation showing all calculations is the best way to answer a 'show that' question.
questions.explanation: Long chains of calculations are confusing and often mathematically incorrect. Use separate, clear steps.
questions.studyTip: Multiple short steps beat one long confusing chain.

questions.text: 'Show that' answers should be structured as separate, clear mathematical statements.
questions.explanation: Step 1: Calculate X. Step 2: Apply to Y. Step 3: Therefore Z. Each statement must be mathematically valid.
questions.studyTip: One calculation per line. Clear and logical progression.

questions.text: If a question says 'use your answer from part (a)', you can recalculate instead.
questions.explanation: Use the answer you got, even if it was wrong. This tests whether you can apply results correctly.
questions.studyTip: Use YOUR answer from earlier, even if you're unsure about it.

questions.text: When instructed to use a previous answer, you must use it even if you think it might be incorrect.
questions.explanation: Marks are awarded for correct application of your earlier answer. Recalculating from scratch may lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Follow instructions. Use your earlier answer as told.

questions.text: If you've done the calculations, the assessor will know which option is better.
questions.explanation: You must state your conclusion explicitly. 'Membership saves $114/year' not just the calculation.
questions.studyTip: Always write a clear conclusion sentence.

questions.text: After calculating values for a comparison, you must explicitly state which option is better and why.
questions.explanation: Don't leave it for the assessor to interpret. State: 'Option A is cheaper because...' or 'The saving is...'
questions.studyTip: Finish with a clear statement answering the question asked.

questions.text: Giving your personal opinion is enough to justify an answer.
questions.explanation: Justification requires evidence from calculations or the data given. 'I think so' isn't a justification.
questions.studyTip: Justify with numbers or data, not opinions.

questions.text: Justifying an answer requires referencing specific data, calculations, or evidence from the question.
questions.explanation: Connect your reasoning to the information provided. 'Because the graph shows...' or 'Since 64% > 50%...'
questions.studyTip: Point to the evidence that supports your answer.

questions.text: Writing more always earns more marks.
questions.explanation: Extra information that's wrong can lose marks. Answer what's asked, nothing more.
questions.studyTip: More writing ≠ more marks. Extra wrong info = lost marks.

questions.text: When a brief answer is sufficient, adding unnecessary extra information can cost marks if it's incorrect.
questions.explanation: If asked for one thing and you provide two (one wrong), you may lose the mark entirely.
questions.studyTip: Answer the question. Stop. Don't add risky extras.

questions.text: If you disagree with information given in the question, you should explain why it's wrong.
questions.explanation: Accept what the question tells you, even if it seems odd. Don't argue with the given facts.
questions.studyTip: The question is always right. Work with what you're given.

questions.text: You should accept values and conditions stated in the question as correct and work with them.
questions.explanation: Some students challenged given information instead of answering the actual question. Don't do this.
questions.studyTip: Given information is given. Use it as stated.

questions.text: You don't need to know the formulas since they're on the formula sheet.
questions.explanation: You need to know which formula to use and how to use it. The sheet doesn't tell you when to apply each one.
questions.studyTip: Know your formulas. The sheet is a reminder, not a teacher.

questions.text: You should be familiar with the formula sheet before the exam so you can quickly locate what you need.
questions.explanation: Know what's there and where to find it. Exam time isn't for learning what the formulas do.
questions.studyTip: Study with the formula sheet. Know it before exam day.

questions.text: If your working is correct, your answer must be correct.
questions.explanation: Transcription errors, calculator mistakes, and misreading happen. Always verify your final answer makes sense.
questions.studyTip: Check: did I answer what was asked? Does it make sense?

questions.text: After completing a question, you should verify your answer is realistic and matches what was asked.
questions.explanation: Does the question ask for %, but you wrote a decimal? Does your 'price' have 5 decimal places? Fix these.
questions.studyTip: Final check: format correct? Value realistic? Question answered?

questions.text: When data is in a table, you can estimate values rather than reading them exactly.
questions.explanation: Tables give exact values. Use them precisely. Estimating when exact data is available loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Table = exact values. Read carefully, copy correctly.

questions.text: Values from tables should be extracted exactly as given, with careful attention to which row/column applies.
questions.explanation: Transcription errors from tables are common. Double-check you're reading the right cell.
questions.studyTip: Use your finger or pen to track rows and columns accurately.

questions.text: For complex problems, try to do everything in one calculation.
questions.explanation: Break complex problems into steps. This reduces errors and allows partial marks if something goes wrong.
questions.studyTip: Complex problem? Break it into steps. Show each one.

questions.text: Breaking complex problems into smaller steps makes working clearer and allows partial marks.
questions.explanation: Step 1: find X. Step 2: use X to find Y. Step 3: apply to get final answer. Each step can earn marks.
questions.studyTip: Small steps = clearer working = more partial marks available.

questions.text: Weekly, monthly, and annual rates are interchangeable without conversion.
questions.explanation: Time periods must match. Weekly rate × 52 = annual. Monthly rate × 12 = annual. Convert correctly.
questions.studyTip: Weekly × 52. Monthly × 12. Daily × 365. Match the time periods.

questions.text: When comparing rates over different time periods, you must convert to the same time period first.
questions.explanation: $100/week vs $400/month? Convert both to annual: $5,200 vs $4,800. Now you can compare.
questions.studyTip: Same time period = fair comparison. Convert first.
